div3.head: Accidents of the War.
div3.p: --The Wilmington of Monday evening, says in reference the telegraphic news of the great battle Richmond.

Terrible as is the public suspense, there is that deeper and more agonizing, and the that pasted over the wires yesterday a gloom over the spirits of the opens themselves, used as they are to such . Aften 9 o'clock we went to the telegraphic office to inquire, and found there a val friend, whose stainer betrayed deep agi. A telegram in his hand, which shook emotion, informed him that his daughter a widow, her husband having fallen the battle at the head of his company-- like the following which is gene with the names omitted, finished over the Madame — Your two sons have to-day martyrs to the cause of their country" such is war; such it always has been and they will be. May He who tempers the to the lamb send help and comfort ones, for He only can.

div3.head: Affairs in North Alabama.
div3.p: The Knoxville Register, of June gets the following items of interest from Col William Hendley, who recently arrived in that city from North Alabama.

Col. Wm. Hudley was taken prisoner by the Yankees but made his escape, swimming his horse across the Tennessee river.
He reports that the Yankees are perpetrating all manner of outrages in the counties of Limestone and Madison, robbing the citizens of money, clothes, bacon, horses, and in fact everything else, unfrequently quartering their horses in the houses of planters and otherwise shooting them, until such a reign of terror has been inaugurated that no citizen dare raise so much as the little Gager by way of profess against the barbarism of the invading force.

Mitchell has signed a proclamation declaring that he will turn every-house in fifty miles of Huntsville, unless bushwhacking is stopped, and the citizens are in such mortal dread of his executing his threat, that the strongest secessionists (hitherto) are now clamoring for submission on the part of the citizens, and many have already taken the , while others are only welting a fitting opportunity to do so. We are glad to hear, however, that Hon. N. N. Davis has at last made his escapes from Huntsville and gone to Corinth to take his place we trust, in the ranks of our brave army there, and thereby disprove all the slanders which have been circulated about him since he has been living, on apparently friendly terms, with the invaders of his native State.
At the same time, we are pained to believe that the Hon. Jere Clemens has gone over to the enemy entirely if all that is said of him be true, he deserves the most condign punishment.
But while the former leaders in that section are growing pale with unmanly fear, and while the men are showing evident signs of weakness in the knees, thank God ! the noble daughters of the South are there, as else where, true to themselves and their country.
Out of many instances of the kind, we will cite the example of only one brave, true-hearted woman, of the noble old Virginia, stock, whose husband is absent in the service of his country, and who is stopping with an aged and infirm father.
Returning to her home on one occasion she found several Lincolnite in the kitchen coolly engaged in cooking their dinners, when, without more ado, she kicked their meal into the fire with her delicate foot, and pointing to the door with her slender fingers, said with the spirit of the true heroine, "there is the door, get you gone, hirelings, and let your own masters feed you" Let your cheeks tingle with shame.
O, white-livered cowards who disgrace the name of Southron, while you read this noble rebuke from the lips of a frail daughter of our own Southern land.

It seems that Gen. Mitchell has one regiment of Chicago Dutch in his command, who were taken by Price at Lexington, but who have broken their parole, and are now fighting as it were with halters about their necks.
They are represented to be the most utterly abandoned wretches to be seen anywhere, being guilty of crimes which decency will not allow us to make public.
Coming from Chicago, they have also sworn vengeance against Col. D. R. Hundley, who was residing there at the same time the war broke out, and who only succeeded in escaping a Chicago Vigilance Committee in disguise and by the help of friends, one short twelve-months ago.

Not satisfied with confiscating his property and the property of his father-in-law, (a gentleman of Virginia,) valued at nearly a million of dollars, they seem bent on wreaking their blind vengeance on him still more, should he ever be so unfortunate as to fall into their hands.
But we have no fears that their bloodthirstiness will ever be gratified, if the four compatibles that filed past our office on last Saturday are a fair sample of the men who go to fill up the ranks of the 31st Alabama; for a nobler set of men have not trod the streets of Knoxville for many a day.

These miserable Yankee Dutch have already begun to arm the negroes with guns taken from the citizens, and a great many of the deluded blacks have been arrested with guns in their hands.
We are glad to learn, however, that even the negroes in the main are more wise than the Trojans of old, and look with not ill-founded suspicion upon the "Greeks bearing gift's"

div3.head: Prospective Redemption of Middle Tennessee.
div3.p: --From a letter published in the Atlanta Confederacy, dated Chattanooga, Tenn, May 30, we copy the following:

During the present week our city has been in a state of wholesome excitement.
There has been marching to and fro of detachment of cavalry, artillery and infantry, and all that bustle and preparation that constitute the preliminaries of a "forward movement." This is no less gratifying to civilians than to the soldier who has seen wasting his energy and his health by the Lutetia of camp life — How a little "Stonewall"-ism, it faced into our military lines throughout their whole extent, would change the aspect of the war, and give us visible evidence of a speedy termination of our struggle !

Governor Harris is now here; also, General Kirby Smith.
I cannot speak by authority as to what movements are under discussion, but it is quite natural to suppose that our Governor thinks that Andy, the Usurper, has occupied his seat as long as the public welfare demands.
Hands an expedition for the recovery of Middle Tennessee is not only a possible, but a very probable event.

There are many refugees from Middle Tennessee now here — among them is Hon. And'w Ewing, and others of note.
A meeting was held by them this morning, and the incipient steps taken for organizing a force from their own number to co-operate with the regular army, for the recovery of their homes and the dise of their action of the State.
The skies are brightening in our beloved Tennessee.
The 2,000 Yankee prisoners that passed through your city last week were taken from hereby steamer, down the river to Bellefonte Landing, where they were turned over to the Federal authorities.

The traffic between this point and Nashville, via McMinnville, is acquiring considerable magnitude, Loaded wagons arrive and depart daily.
Tobacco is the principal article exported, white shoes, stationery, dry goods, and articles that will visit the most excessive profits, are brought in return.
This trade, contrary as it is to the spirit and letter of the laws between belligerent powers, and demoralizing as it is upon those engaged, is suffered to go on with impunity, although we have military and martial law in full blast, and Brigadiers and Provosts to protect the rights of our Confederacy.

div3.head: Candid
div3.p:
--A letter, written by the Rev. A. A. Haines, pastor of a church in the interior of New York, to a soldier in the Federal army, was picked up on the battle-field.
We copy a single paragraph:

The war news just now is very uninteresting.
I fear our Generals are not qualified to make much Bradway, and with an our great army and navy, the South is as strong as ever.
The English and French will perhaps take the part of the South in a few months, and then our poor country may be crushed before the combined efforts of her numerous foes.
But God is our trust, and let us hope and pray we may have peace soon again, and all our dark apprehensions dissipated.

div3.head: Poisoning
div3.p:
--We learn that yesterday morning several members of Capt Smith's company, belonging to Col. McKinstry's regiment, left their camp a short distance, and in the woods found a bottle, which they supposed contained whisky.
They drank freely of it, and brought it into camp and gave some to the Sergeant of the company.
In all there were five men who drank a portion of the contents of the bottle.
In an hour or two all five of the man died.
The bottle contained several kinds of roots and herbs, but it is not positively known what they were, except that there was quite a quantity of yellow jessamine in it.

It is the belief in camp that some one had mixed himself up a bottle of medicine which should have been taken in small quantities, but the unfortunate mad had taken an over-doze--Mobile Tribune, 29th.

div3.head: A Lincolnite Adulterer killed.
div3.p:
--We learn from a citizen of Chattanooga, that a noted Lincolnite, called 'Squire Brown, a man of property, residing rear Chattanooga, has been insulting the wives of several Confederate soldiers, who were absent in the army, and, on one occasion, whipped a lady whose charity would not yield to his solicitations.
Her husband came home, and, hearing of his diabolical conduct, proceeded to his house, on Sunday last, and deliberately shot him. He died in half an hour forfeited his life for his villainy--Knoxville Register.

div3.head: Escaped
div3.p:
--Captain Aston Madeira, of the 2d Kentucky regiment, who, with his entire company, was taken prisoner at Fort Donelson, has escaped from Columbus, Ohio, and is now safe in Canada, where he was received, and whence he writes that he will soon had find his way back to his duties in the South.
He states that he has more friends and money than he ever had in his life.

Rev Dr. Tiffany, represented as one of the most prone and eloquent divines in that God forsaken city, Chicago, started on a mission of mercy to the Federal army at Pittsburg Landing.
On the way he got so gloriously drunk that his friends had to look him up in a state room on the boat.
Gen. S. R. Chandler, a prominent citizen of Sumter District, S. C., died last Saturday week.
The British steamer Netly, ashore on Long Island Beath, below Charleston, was sold on Tuesday last for $1,700 cash.
Some of the Georgia papers upbraid Gen. Robert Toombs for planting an unusually large crop of cotton.
All restriction upon the removal of salt from Charleston to the interior of South Carolina has been withdrawn.
Sir William Don, the actor, died in Australia March last.

div3.head: The Lines.
div3.p:
The loud and heavy reports of ordnance, heard at dusk on Saturday evening, gave rise to divers reports of amusing and preposterous dimensions, yet, as usual, not one of the marvellous stories had any, or the slightest warranty in fact, since the cannonading simply arose from artillerists discharging their "wet loads" in some one of the batteries on or near the Mechanicville Turnpike, and nothing more.
In fact, the state of the Lines on Saturday was more than usually quiet and monotonous — brigade commanders were particularly zealous in sending gentle for the arrest of stragglers, decoyed and delayed in town by metropolitan pleasures — and we were particularly pleased that our streets were relieved of scores of military men, whose presence was, or might be, required at the front.
In addition to these facts we remarked, that our suggestions regarding the roads had met with practical approval from heads of departments, and that heavy details were fast improving their condition; so much so indeed, that in many places they are now passable and practicable for all purposes.

On Sunday the discharge of artillery at various points, front, led many to believe that serious operations were then progressing; but proceeding to the line of fire on the left, we found that nothing serious had transpired, and that the salves were from artillerists discharging wet loads, as on Saturday evening. It is true there was some musketry fire but this took place from double cause.
Immediately to our front, on Garnett's farm, there is a patch of woods which the pickets have vacated for several days, and the Federals, not knowing the fact, were determined to find out our true position.
Accordingly, in a very Quixotic mood, they appeared in force, and valiantly charged the vacant woods.
Our artillery coming up and opening opportunity, quickly dispersed them again, killing and wounding several.
Since the artillery duello at this point, the enemy have shown much prudence and discretion, not trusting them.
selves beyond their earthworks, as before.
On the right of our line, also, artillery firing occurred yesterday morning, but from what actual cause, or with what result, we have been unable to ascertain, and have not, as yet, been advised.

The only fight that really occurred yesterday took place between the sixth and seventh mile posts of the York River R. R., and advocate to the track, between the enemy and some of Hood's Texan brigade.
It appears that details were made from the 1st, 4th and 5th Texan regiments, to proceed to the front for the purpose of digging rifle pits, and having stacked arms in the wood, were peacefully working with spades, when the enemy, discovering and disliking such excavations, made demonstrations of a warlike nature, and endeavored to drive the Texans away — Not able to effect their object, reinforcements were sent to assist them, when the Texans seized their trusty rifles, and delivered such murderous volleys that five regiments of the enemy did not suffice to contend against them.
The firing was rapid and constant for more than an hour, but the enemy appearing an masse, the Texans were unerring in aim, and each brought down his man at every fire.
After some eighty minutes skirmishing, the enemy left the field, deserting their killed and wounded, to the number of forty or fifty. Two wounded Federalists were brought to town, who verify our report, adding that the firing of the Texans was so accurate, and their movements to the woods so cunning and Indian-like, that they never wish to make their acquaintance again.
The Yankees had the same report to make of Hood's brigade at West Point, where these same brave boys drove them, ignominiously, to their gunboats.
We learn that among the men of the brigade detail, (some 40), perhaps, in number not more than five or six were hit--one of the 4th and 5th being wounded, and one of the 1st regiment (D. D. Davis) killed.
This gentleman, who untimely fell in the gallant skirmish of yesterday, was editor and proprietor of the Parts (Lamar, co. Tense.) Press, and was of brilliant parts, a good soldier, and had rendered our common cause much good as a soldier and scribe.
He was not detailed to go with the working party yesterday, but being of an adventurous turn of mind, volunteered, as he had frequently done on previous occasions.

div3.head: The death of Col. Ashby.
div3.p:
From dispatches received in this city yesterday, we learn that Col. Ashby was killed in a skirmish on Friday last, somewhere in the vicinity of Harrisonburg.
We were 10th to believe this painful report, but later dispatches seem to confirm it. On Wednesday Col. Ashby had a skirmish near Harrisonburg, in which he captured several prisoners — among them Sir Percy Worden, an English baronet, but now a Colonial in the Federal service.
We have received no authentic information regarding the skirmish in which the gallant Colonel lost his life, and do not care to circulate the rumor current upon the streets yesterday evening.
Since the first invasion of Virginia, Col. Ashby has been actively engaged in the service, and probably no man has done more or better work.
Thoroughly acquainted with the country, constantly on the alert, active and brave, he has hung about the lines of the enemy, harassing them until his very name has become a terror.
His death will be a serious loss to the Confederacy, and his place difficult to fill.

div3.head: Northern account of the late battle.
div3.p:
A gentleman who saw a New York paper of Wednesday last, informs us that the Federals admit a loss of 800 killed and 4,000 wounded in the late battle below this city.
As might have been expected, they assert that the Confederate loss is much heavier, though they acknowledge that the "Rebels" fought desperately.
Among the Federals killed are three Brigadier- Generals, whose names we could not learn.

div3.head: Death of J. J. Hooper.
div3.p:
We are sorry to learn that J. J. Hooper, Esq, late Secretary of the Provisional Congress, died in this city Saturday night, after a short illness.
For Audry years Mr. Hooper has been well known throughout this country as a racy and brilliant worker of everyday sketches, and as a political editor.
Among his earlier writings were some admirable articles for the old Spirit of the Lines, which, at the time, attracted considerable attention.
His first book was "Simon Suggs," a work of its kind, and which has obtained a world wide reputation for keen wit and genuine satire.
For several years past Mr. Hooper has been connected with the Montgomery (Ala.) Mail, which paper he conducted up to a little more than a year ago. When the Provisional Congress met in Montgomery, Mr. Hooper was elected Secretary, and held this office during the Provisional year.
He was about forty years of age, a man of great talent, of unbounded liberal and beloved by all who knew him. our.
Hooper was from Montgomery, Alabama, at which place his family now reside.

div3.head: Gen. Pettigrew not dead.
div3.p:
From a flag of truce which communicated with the enemy on Friday we learn that Gen. Pettigrew was not killed as at first reported, but that he was wounded and a prisoner of war. His captures was swing to his own while wounded on the field, be commanded those who were hearing him off to return to their posts and leave him to his fate.
His wound, although serious, is reported as doing well Col. Lightfoot and Lt. Col. Long, of the Twenty-Second North Carolina, were also supposed to be among the killed; but we have learned by the flag of truce that they were neither injured in the battle, and that they are now prisoners in the Federal army.

A young man named William Ashton, of Charleston, S. C., committed suicide in Mobile, on Saturday week, by shooting himself.
He is supposed to have been partially deranged.

div3.head: From Jackson.
div3.p:
We have information from Jackson's army up to Saturday, at which time his headquarters were at Port Republic, in Rockingham, and it was thought possible he might retire before the force pressing upon his line, unless indeed, an opportunity for an attack was offered.
The enemy was reported to be between Woodstock and Harrisonburg, and near the latter place.
The reported victory appears to have arisen from a mere skirmish between the advance of the Yankees and our rear guard, from which the Yankee press seems to have derived considerable consolation.
Notwithstanding the overwhelming numbers sent against Jackson, we have no fears for his safety, feeling confident he will extricate himself from all difficulties, and give the Yankee Generals another opportunity for a strategic run across the Potomac.

div3.head: Major-General Hill's Address to the 12th Mississippi regiment.
div3.p:
While the 12th Mississippi regiment was drawn up in line of battle on Thursday, the 5th inst, Major-General Hill, commanding the division in which it operates, rode up and addressed it relative to its conduct in the recent battle before Richmond.
The substance of his remarks was as follows:

Twelfth Mississippi: I witnessed with my own eyes your on the battle field on Saturday, and I am proud to say that you maintained your ground heroically amid the deadly storm of grape, canister, shell, and musketry.
With you there was now no unsteadiness, no lagging behind, but "toward, still onward," you pressed towards the enemy with a spirit of valor which it did my very heart good to witness, and the full events it's efforts me much pleasure thus politely accord you. The troops of his have won Laurie's for her upon every field, wherever they have been engaged, and your gallant on Saturday can but add new leisure to her name.
I love Mississippi as I do my own native State.
There resides my only brother, and beneath its hallowed soil repose the last remains of a beloved mother.
Mississippians from the bottom of my heart, I thank you.

div3.head: Col. Williams.
div3.p:
Col. L. B. Williams, of the 1st Virginia Regiment, who was badly wounded in the battle of Williamsburg, is so far recovered as to be considered entirely out of danger.
He is still a prisoner in the hands of the enemy.

div3.head: Memphis.
div3.p:
--A rumor comes by the way of Mobile that Memphis has been evacuated since our army left Corinth; that all the cotton, and so much of sugar, molasses and tobacco as was not needed by the inhabitant, were burnt by the authorities, and all the public stores removed.
The rumor also includes the evacuation of Fort Pillow.
We have no positive information on the subject.

div4.p: By the Rev J. B. Jeter, on the 5th inst., at the residence of the bride's father, Mrs. S. S. Carter and Miss M. F. Saunders, all of this city.
On 28th day of May, last, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Joshua Petersen, D. D, Mr. David M. Lea to Sallied, daughter of William Palmer, Esq., of this city.
On Sunday, the 8th inst., at 3 o'clock P. M., Ida Frances, infant child of Alfred and Mclile A. Jennings.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her grandfather, W. W. Ower, between Byrd and arch streets, to-day at ten o'clock.

At the residence of Mr. F. E. Kendrick.
In this city, on the 6th inst, Mr. Fort.
Blackwell, a member of the Ashland in this 22d year.

In recording the death of this good young man we can but say that he is at rest.
His was one among the first to enlist in his country's cause and while in came contracted a disease from which he was aware he would never recover, and died while praising the Lamb.
May his bereaved parents and relatives derive consolation from the above.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p:
It is with feelings of profound regret, but humble submission, th chronicle the death of Capt. J. T. Gibson, Company H, Fire.
Arkansas regiment, who was mortally wounded at the battle of Shiloh, April 6, lingering twenty-four hours, suffering intense agony and pain.
The bullet did its deadly work when, for the third time, he was leading has brave boys to the charge, he himself thirty or forty yards in advance, calling on them to follow.
Thus fell a noble, true, and honest patriot.
Captain Gibson, though a native of North Carolina, had been living several years in Arkansas, practising his profession, the law with marked success and ability.
After a short residence in the State of his adoption, he was sent to the Legislature, and was a prominent member of that body at the time of his death.
He was dearly loved by his company, and many in the regiment envied his popularity when, at there organization, he was by exclamation re-elected.

Captain Gibson possessed a disposition which rendered him attractive to all — gentle emotional and kind, though highly gifted, he made no attempt at display, or endeavored again admiration, but always succeeded in winning love.
After being borne from the field, he spoke but little, devoting most of the time to prayer, thanking God for staring him a little time for preparation.
Be died perfectly reconciled; from this I know his was a Christian's death.
His last written thoughts were to her whom he tenderly loved was, far away in Virginia; and to her I say, "Weep not; he died hobly — a Christian patriot.
* A Friend

div3.head: Military Surgery.
div3.p:
West & Johnston,
145 Main street,
Have recently published--

A Manual of military Surgery for the use of Surgeons in the Confederate States Army with an Appendix of the Bides and Regulation of the Medical Department of the Confederate States Army.
By J. Jailen Chisolm M. D., Professor of Surgery in the Medical College of South Carolina, Surgeon in the Confederate States Army; second edition revived and improved Prices $ ; by such postage paid, $3.60.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --At a meeting of the ladies of the First Baptist Church and congregation, held on Sabbath, the 8th inst., after service, the following resolutions were unanimously adopted:

list.item: 1st.Resolved. That the ladies of this Church and congregation — with the consent of the Government — will co-operate with those of the other Baptist Churches in the city, and any other benevolent ladies, in attendance upon a hospital in the building of the Richmond Female Institute.
2d. Resolved, That the male members of the above named Churches and congregations be requested to furnish such pecuniary and personal aid as may be needed.

div3.p: The ladies of the various Baptist Churches in the city and any others interested in the object, are requested to assemble in the First Baptist Church on this (Monday) morning, at 10 o'clock, to make arrangements to carry into effect the foregoing resolutions.

Fearing that the ladies who have so generously contributed to aids Hospital may doubt that the constitutions have been received, I take this method of informing them that each article has promptly come to hand — it's bandages, old linen, and food of every variety in -- The ladies with please receive the great acknowledgments of the Surgeon in charge and all the officers of the Hospital, for their generous effort to aid us in calling for and wounded soldiers, Hereafter when are given, I would suggest that they be sent uncooked.
div3.closer:
St. Geo. Phachy P. A. C. E.
charge,
19th st. bet. 31 in end Franklin. ja 9--1t

div3.head: Daily Union Prayer meeting
div3.p: --The daily Prayer Meetings, and the suspects of the Young Men's Christian Association, chiefly to supplicates the Divine blessings upon our Confederacy, will be held every afternoon this week at 8½ o'clock in the Broad Street Methodist Church, (Rev. Dr. Doggett) on the corner of Broad and 10th streets Pastors and congregations, and strangers in the city, are invited to attend and participate in the meetings.

div3.head: Mare and Colt for sale.
div3.p:
A young Mare and Colt for sale at a bargain.
Can be seen in the yard on Cary street, between 1st and 2d. Price . Any one wanting them can find the subscriber at the corner of Main and 8th streets.

div3.head:
Redeye.
a fine
bay Horse.
div3.p:
5 years old, by Red Eye, for sale.
Can be seen at my between Grace and Franklin, near 6

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--Large and well famished Rooms for gentlemen; with good attendance, on Grace street, two doors above Adams, within a square of three nice boarding-houses, where meals can be be procured.
Call between 3 and 10 o'clock A. M., or from 4 to 6 in the afternoon.

div3.head:
Reported Assassination of Andy Johnson and Picayune Butler.
skirmish at Baton Rouge.
div3.p: --It is reported at Mobile that a citizen of Nashville, named George Brown, had killed Andy Johnson, and that Brown had also been killed.
It is reported at Vicksburg float Gen. Butter had been killed in New Orleans, but the report lacks confirmation.
The Jackson Mississippian, of the 3d instant, says that a small detachment of Gen. Lovell's forces attacked the Federals at Baton Rouge, on Sunday night, killing twenty-one of the enemy.

div3.head: Federal attack near Jasper, Tenn
div3.p: --Gen. Adams was attacked yesterday by a superior force of the enemy, supposed to be 4,000 strong, Infantry, cavalry, and artillery, about twelve miles Northwest of Jasper, Tenn, and was compelled to retreat, with a less of six men; The enemy are not near here.

div3.head: Information wanted
div3.p:
--Of Edward Kennard and Thos Smith, who were sent from Summit Point . They are either in one of the Hospitals or at some private house.
Any one knowing anything about them will please report at my camp, on the Brook Turnpike, near Chickahominy, or to Johnston & Bransford, Richmond.

div3.head: Information wanted

div3.head: Interesting facts and incidents from the Tract distributors.

opener.salute: To the Editors of the Dispatch:

div3.p: The following extracts from the letters of persons who are laboring for the spiritual good of our soldiers will doubtless be of interest to many of your readers:

Rev W. Huff writes from Marion, Va: "I have visited the hospitals at Bristol, Abingdon, Saltville, Wytheville, and Emory and Henry College.
There are three hundred sick at Emory and — Henry, and the number will soon be augmented to one thousand.
The demand for Testaments is very gratefully one-half being destitute of them.
I collect large quantities of Bibles, and other books, from the country people; am now making up a library for Emery and henry hospital.
The tracts are read with interest and fit A soldier, after reading Dr. Jeter's tract on swearing, remarked to a friend that he would never again utter as cash. The President of the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad has kindly presented me with a free ticket, so that I can very easily reach all the hospitals and camps along this road."

Rev. W. L. Fetcher, Petersburg, Virginia: "For nine months I have been riding from camp to camp, distributing testaments and tracts in the Norfolk and Suffolk armies.--Now that they have fallen back, I have made this place my headquarters, and will labor in the hospitals and the camps around."

Rev. B. B. Ross, Corinth, Mississippi: "I have distributed all of the three boxes of tracts and books you shipped.
I secured the co-operation of three pasters and two chaplains.
I saw two ministers from Holly Springs, where there are four hospitals.
They promised me to order Testaments and tracts from you and to supply those hospitals.
The tracts are read with interest, and I might give many incidents illustrative of the good they are effecting.
But the clamor is for Testaments.
Those with palms are especially sought for. Souls, thousands of them, are perishing for lack of knowledge."

Rev. Mr. Ross is the Methodist Presiding Elder of Mobile, but thinking that now he might do more good among the soldiers, he has gone to Corinth to act as our agent there, in looking out pious men and inducing them to become tract distributors.

Miss A., of Fincastle: "The packages of tracts you have sent have been received and distributed.
Allow me to thank you for the privilege of assisting in this delightful work.
Two weeks ago I learned that the 2nd Virginia regiment would pass within five miles of this place on route for Public Depot.
Being anxious to give them tracts, I walked out to the road, where the soldiers were resting in the shade.
Brethren Corron and Ellison accompanied us. The soldiers came around us faster than we could hand them out. Numbers would say, 'Please give me a tract;' others, to whom I had given one, would soon return and beg for another, so that in the course of an hour I had given away one thousand one hundred and twelve tracts.
They seemed particularly fond of the large ones, as they contained more reading matter.
Many were affected by the work entitled 'A mother's parting words to her soldier boy,' having left behind them pious mothers.
Many said that they had nothing to read for months.
Numbers were destitute of Testaments — some never having had any, while others had lost theirs in hasty retreats'

Rev. J. M. B. Roach, Chaplain 10th regiment Alabama volunteers, writes: "You may be assured that our soldiers read with deep interest your tracts.
I have seen much of their good effects among my regiment.
Just before entering the battle at Williamsburg a Lieutenant asked for a copy of each of my tracts; he folded them up, about a dozen, and placed them in his side pocket.
During the fight a ball pierced the tracts and lodged against the tract nearest his body.
He attributes the saving of his life to the obstruction afforded by the tracts, and is now apparently much interested in religious matters."

Wm. T. Sutherlin, Chairman.
Danville, 11th May, 1862,
Esleigh; Greensboro', and Danville papers copy until 11th June.

div3.head: The National defence Association Basaar.
div3.p: --This association has engaged sisgatn rooms, corner of Broad and ninth streets, for a Basaar, and will be ready to receive donations of all kinds on next Monday.

All communications should be addressed to Mrs. V. E. W., Vernon.
Box 846, Manager of Hasasr, and Corresponding Secretary of N. D. A

Office Provost Marshal,
May 14th, 1862.
div3.p: notice — All persons who have deposited money with Capt. Alexander, Assistnat Provost Marshal,as security, will, on and after to-Morrow, May 15th, call at the office of the Provost Marshal, corner of Broad and 9th streets, and get their money.

opener.salute: To the Men of Richmond and Vicinity:

div4.p:
The necessity of embodying; in some available form, and for some good service, all men able to do duty in this trying hour, is apparent; for the destiny of our State, our city, and, it may be, of the country and the cause we love, depends now greatly upon the energy and the power of the Confederate arms to be displayed in the next few weeks or months.--The urgent demand for soldiers already trained to arms makes it necessary to call all such, in and around Richmond, to the field, whilst the indispensable services of a city guard are under this necessity lost, and interests important to Richmond and to the Confederacy may be, in a great measure, neglected.
That there are five hundred men in and around our city true to the cause of the South, and who would rather die upon the hills of Richmond, in defence of their homes and of Virginia, than live to witness their desecration and dishonor — men who have not yet taken up arms, and yet who are both able and willing — I will not doubt.

At the suggestion, and by authority of the Secretary of War, and aided by the co-operation of the Council of the city, as exhibited below, I announce my desire and purpose, if possible, to organize the battalion indicated as speedily as possible, and that the public may have confidence and act understandingly in enrolling their names, I indicate the following gentlemen, all soldiers, who have consented, and who are hereby authorized to enroll each a company of one hundred men, and who will command the same if the requisite number be raised and the battalion organized, viz:
Louis J. Bossieux,
Wm. L. Maule,
John H Greaner,
J. F. C. Potts,
Wm. Wirt Harrison.

With each of these well known citizens may be found a roll, with a caption setting forth the terms of enrollment, and to one or another of them, all persons disposed to engage in this service are referred.
The term of service will be six months unless sooner discharged, and the duties to be performed, any to which the battalion may be assigned within the limits indicated.
If to be made available for any good purpose the battalion must be formed promptly, and no organization will be attempted until the requisite number have been enrolled by each of the gentlemen whose names have been given above.

div4.head:
War Department,
Richmond, May 29th, 1862.
div4.p:
You are authorized to raise five companies for local and special service within the circuit of the batteries around Richmond and Manchester, the said companies to be organized into a battalion, of which you will be commissioned Major — the company officers elected.
These officers must be returned in the caption of the muster rolls to the Adjutant General.
The companies must be regularly organized as required for like companies in general service, and men of all ages, not actually in service, may be accepted.

At a meeting of the Council of the city of Richmond, June 3d, 1862.
at 5 o'clock P. M., the following preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted:
The Secretary of War having authorized W. M. Elliott to raise a battalion for the defence of this city for the term of six months: Therefore--

Resolved, That the Council of the city of Richmond will appropriate twenty dollars per month, as beauty to each non-commissioned officer and private who may enlist in said battalion, the date of his bounty to commence at the time of mustering into service, and end with the term of service or when they are disbanded.
div4.closer: A copy: A. W. Morton, C. C. j-7--2t

div3.head:
Adjutant General's Office
Richmond, Va., May 4, 1862,

div4.p: The following General Order, No. 1, of Major General John B. Floyd, is to be respected and promptly obeyed by all persons who have received or may receive commissions, or appointments to raise companies, battalions or regiments to for the line of State Troops.

The Governor earnestly but confidently appeals to all men who are able to bear arms, and who are not now in the field, to rally to the standard of the State, under the gallant officer who has been invested with the command of her troops.
Recruiting and mustering officers will forward their returns to Major General Floyd at his headquarters, or otherwise, as he may direct, and send duplicates to this office.
Orders for transportation, when needed, will be issued here.
div4.closer:
By command.
Wm. B. Richardson, A. G.

div4.head:
Richmond, May 30th, 1862.
General order, no 1.

list.item:
1.
The address of many persons proposing to raise companies for service in the Virginia State Line, commanded by Major-General John B. Floyd, has not been left with the Adjutant General of the State.
The authority to do so, if not forwarded to said persons, can be had at the office of the Adjutant General of Virginia Forces, Richmond.
2. The persons to whom such authority is given are hereby constituted recruiting and mustering officers for said service.

3. Such officers will swear and muster into service, immediately after their enlistment such persons as enlist.
The men thus sworn and mustered will be entirely to commutation of rations, at the rate of seventy-five cents per day, until rations can be furnished them in stud.

4. The points of General Rendezvous for the troops of this command are Wytheville, Wythe county. Va., and Goodson.
Washington county. Va. To these places they will be sent as soon after they have been sworn and mustered, and in such numbers as may em best to the recruiting officer.
Transportation will be furnished them upon the certificate of the recruiting officer, that they have been sworn and mustered into service.
5. Recruiting Stations will be opened at the following places: Richmond, Petersburg, Lynchburg Staunion, Union, Monroe county, Fincas c, Charlottesville, Farmville, Hillsville, Carroll county.

div4.closer:
By order:
Major-General John R. Floyd,
Commanding Virginia State Lina,
Wm. E. Peters, A. A. A. G. je 3--6t

div3.head: City Battalion.
div3.p: --The undersigned having been authorized to recruit a Company for the Battalion to be raised for local defence Maj. Wyatt M. Elliott, commanding, have opened a Recruiting Office in the store of Mr John C. Page, 93 Main street, between 14th and 15th
The command is to be stationed within the limits of the city certifications and thus affords a splendid opportunity to those who are desirous of being in the service.
In addition to the regular pay, the city gives a bounty of twenty dollars per month to each private and commissioned officer.
Further particulars given at the rendezvous, which will be open from 8 to 1, and from 3t 6.

div3.head:
Adj't General's Office, Va.,
June 4th, 1862.
div3.p:
all men from 35 to 55 years of age, whatever they have furnished substitution in companies which are in the field or not, are bound to do duty with the second class ia, and must perform that duty.
Battalion and company officers will be rigid and inflexible in enforcing it upon all delinquents.
div3.closer:
By command.
Wm. H. Richardson. A. G. j 5--3t

div3.head: $30 reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted from my company, at Camp Winder, private John Kaylor, a substitute.
Said Kaylor is about 5 foot 8 inches high, dark complexion, light hair, and hazel eyes, is about 21 years old, was mustered in on the 23 ult.; left that night, and has not been since.
I will pay the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said Kaylor to the Provost Marshal.

I am authorized by the Governor of Virginia, under the act of May 15th, 1862, to raise a Regiment of Cavalry, to serve under Major-General Floyd.
Men wishing to enlist, and officers desiring to raise Companies, or assist to the organization, can get authority to do so by seeing or addressing me by letter at this place.
My office for the present will be at my residence, on South side of Franklin street, next door to second.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Adj Partisan Corps,
Richmond, May 28, 1862.
div3.p: the undersigned having received authority to organize a
Partisan Corps of Marylanders, invites all young men from that state to join his corps, which will be composed of cavalry, artillery and infantry.

Horses will be furnished to the cavalry, if requested.
Pay, rations and bounty the same as in regular service, and the value of all captures divided in the corps.
Marylanders enlisted for 12 months, including those who have re-enlisted, can obtain transfers to this corps.
Recruiting office at Maj. J. A. Weston's Counting Room, No. 15 Pearl street.

div3.head: Attention, Martin's Battery!
div3.p: --All members of this command who are absent without leave, will report at once at "Camp Lee, " or they will be reported to the Provost Guard and arrested as deserters.
Persons wishing to join the company will apply to Serg't Pulliam, at the Recruiting office, corner of Bank and 12th streets.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig ding.

div3.head:
Headq'rs 33rd Va. Reg't.
June 4th, 1862.
General order.
div3.p: All absentees from the 33rd Virginia regiment are hereby notified that unless they report in person or certificate of some respectable physician within five days, they will be considered deserters and treated accordingly.

Capts, Wm. H. Badgett and Ralph C. Herndon will arrest all absentees from my regiment in Pittsylvania county. Lieut. John S. Field will arrest all those in Mecklenburg and Capt. Jed, Carter those in Halifax.

Serg't Jones M. Gunn, and privates John E Davis, Wm, L. Davis, Y. B. Jones, Wilcy Meade, Joseph Burks, and Joseph Reese, are absent without leave and will be treated as deserters unless they return immediately.

div3.head:
[Extract.]
Adj't and Insp'r Gen's Office,
Richmond,June 5, 1862.
special orders, no. 179.
div3.p:
XII.
Surgeons in charge of Hospitals will forthwith report to this office the number of patients, and the number, names, company, and regiment, of detailed men acting as nurses, &c., in each of their respective Hospitals.
Until such report is sent in no further details will be made.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
John Withers, A. A. G. je 6--1w

div3.p: I am authorized by the Governor of Virginia to raise a Battery of Light Artillery,

for service under Major-General John B. Floyd.--As the number of batteries to be attached to the Division is limited, persons desiring to enlist in this favorite arm of the scarce, had better apply early.
Subsistence furnished from date of enlistment.
Recruiting office, No. 148 Main st.

div3.head:
Battery no. Va.,
De Gouenty's Battalion,
Mechanicville Turnpike, June 6 1862.
div3.p: all members of my Company absent without the proper authority are hereby ordered to report to me immediately, or they will be advertised and treated as deserters.
$10 reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to me, at Battery No. 3, of each of the following deserters:
J. M. Melton, dark eyes, hair, and complexion: 6 feet 1 inch high, age 18 years.
O Melton, dark eyes, black hair, and dark complexion; 5 feet 6 inches high, age 27 years.
P. Y. Melton, dark eyes, hair, and complexion; 6 feet 1 inch high, age 30 years.

W. E. Lucas, light eyes and hair, and fair complexion; 5 feet 8½ inches high.
Were a gray uniform on leaving camp.
Jno. Ford, light gray eyes, sandy hair, ruddy complexion, reddish beard, 5 feet 9 inches high.
The above reside in and around Hungary, Hanover county.
J. E. Cosby, dark eyes, hair, and complexion; 5 feet 11 inches high — in supposed to be lurking in and around the city of Richmond.
div3.closer:
By order. T. P. Wilkinson,
Capt. com'g Allen Artillery. jy 4--6t*

div3.head: Thirty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted, on the 16th day of April, 1862, at or near Richmond Private Spotswood F. Garton, a member of Company B. 19th regiment Virginia volunteers.
Said Garton is thought to be lurking about Ivy Depot, Albemarle county, Va.--The above reward will be paid for the said Garton when delivered to me, at the camp of the 19th regiment Virginia volunteers, near Richmond, Garton is about 23 years old; light hair; light blue eyes, thick set; five feet nine or ten inches high; quick spoken, and is a resident of Albemarle county, Va.
div3.closer:
R. West Wirt, Lieut, Com'g Co. B,
General Longstreet's Division,
3d Brigade. je 4--6*

div3.head: Maryland Partisan Corps.
div3.p: --The undersigned, late Captain of company C, 1st Maryland regiment, is Organizing a Cavalry Company, to be attached to the Partisan Corps of Col. W. H. Jenifer.
Having all the men of my former command, I require but few more to fill up my complement.

Pay, ration, and bounty, same as in he regular service, and, in addition hereto, the value of all captures from the enemy will be distributed among the men. Horses furnished if required. --Parties desirous of enlisting will apply at Major Weston's counting-room, No. 15 Pearl street.

div3.head:
Montgomery
White Sulphur Springs,
Virginia.
div3.p:
This place will be open to the public on the 1st day of June.
It will be kept in as good style as the circumstances of the counry will permit.
Board $12 per week — sevants and children half price.
div3.closer:
Jno. N. Lyes,
for the Proprietors. my 29--1m*

div3.head: Buffalo Springs.
div3.p:
--Having leased this celebrated watering place,in Mecklenburg county, for the balance of the year, I am prepared to entertain guests in the best manner.
From four hundred to four hundred and fifty persons can be comfortably accommodated.
The location is remote from the theatre of war, and yet accessible to travel, being only eight miles from the terminus of the Roanoke Valley Railroad at Clarksville, and twelve miles from Wolf Tran, on the Danville Railroad.
The mineral proporties of the water are universally regarded by those acquainted with it as equal to any water in Virginia.
The public of Richmond city are referred for particulars to Messrs. C. W. Purcell & Co., Bacon & Backervill, Wm. Jetar, John E. White, and Wm. R. Pugh.

div3.head: A Melia Sulphur Springs, Amelia county, Va.
div3.p: This celebrated watering place is located 13 miles southwest of Richmond on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, two and a half miles from Jetersville station, at which place there will be an emnibe in readiness to convey passengers to the Springs, on the 10th day of May, 1862.
Board for one month. (28 days)...$40,00
Children under ten years of age...$20,00
White Servants...$25,00
Colored Servants...$20,00
Board per week...$12,50
Board per day...$2,50
For all meals sent to rooms extra charges will be made.
div3.closer:
N. F. &F. G. Willson,
Proprietors.
N. B — Visitors would do well to bring their blankets with them. my 2--2m*

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p:
--The concern of Wm. T. Moore & Co. dissolved on the 1st of April by mutual consent.
All those indebled to the concern will make payment to Wm. T. Moore, as he alone is authorized to collect them.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The partnership exciting between Blair & Harvir having been dissolved, Mr. W. P. Mate has taken our stand and will continue the business in his own name.
We recommend him to our customers and request them to patronize him.
div3.closer:
Blairs & Harvie,

div3.p: Wm. P. Mayo, successor to Messrs. Blars & Harivis, will continue al, their stand, corner of 11th and Cart Streets, the Geanary and Produce business, where he will be pleased to serve his friends and those of of Messrs. Blair &Harvis.

div3.head: Dissolution of Co.partnership.
div3.p: The partnership heretofore existingf under the style of A. Bodeker & Co., having expired January 1, 1863, by limitation, and the decease of Mr. Wm. Bodeker, the undersigned has associated with himself Mr. W. M. Dade and hit brother, Mr. Henry Bodeker, on the semetms that existed in the former concern, and will continue the Drug and Apothecary business slt old stand, No. 10 Main street, under the same name.
Thankful for the past liberal patronage bestowed on them, they hope, by strict and faithful atttention to their business, to merit a good share to the same in future.

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p: --The co-partnership T. Vanlew, Taylor & Co. is this day dissolved.

Having purchased the interest of C. M. Pleasants, the surviving partner, Johnn.
Vanlew, will hereafter conduct the business in hit own name.
All persons indebted to the old concern, will please sell and sattle with the undersigned.

James D. Browne's
Ornamental Iron works,
9th street, next to the Mechanics' Institute. Iron Railings, Verandahs, Balconies, Charg, Settees, &c.; also, Grating Vault and Cellar Doors, and every other kind of Iron work for ornamental and building purposes, manufactured at short notice.
Particular attention given to enclosing the lal lots in the city and country

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --our senior partner, Mr. Moore being in the army, we have for the present ed our store.
Our books will be found at the store of Mr. Jno. Dolley, who is authorized to receipt in settlement of all accounts.
Those indebted to us will greatly oblige us by calling and exiting the amount of their second is as early as possible.
P. T. Moore. & Co.

div3.head: City Venger--
div3.p: To Citizens of the City of Richmond.--Glenss to leave your orders with Mr. Devol. corner of 10th and Main streets, and at paugh & Johnston's, corner of Main and 18th streets,

div3.head: A very desirable Farm for sale,
div3.p:
containing 283 acres, 60 acres of original growth, heavily timbered, and a large portion of thenrable land highly improved with glover. The improvements consitst attached; all of the necessary out-houses, some just built; a beautiful young orchard, just in hearing; and a well of the best waster in the country; very well fixed.
The farm lies in the county of Cumberland, within six miles of New Canton, and ten of Cartersville.
My object for selling, is to remove to another place recently purchased.
For further particulars, address

div3.head: Land for sale.
div3.p:
--I offer my Farm of 775 acres of land lying in the county of Charlotte, on Spring proof, between the Court-House and Keysville Depot, eight miles from the former place and three from the latter, adjoining the lands of Capt. Sam. F. McGence, David Morton, and others for sale.
This farm possesses many advantages to the farmer, being abundantly watered from springs and creeks of the purt water running through the entire farm affording an average proportion of valuable battom land capable of producing the finest crops of grain and tobacco.
The soil naturally productive and easily cultivated; a sufficiency of timber of original growth conveniently situated; farbing an abundance of the very finest plant land.
The residence, a large two story brick building of the best work manship, with large airy rooms, and two large cellar rooms convenient as dining-rooms,is beautifully situated in a large oak grove, overlooking the sconery around, with a large brick hitchen, brick smoke-house, ice-house, and first rate corn mill in a few bundred yeards of the dwelling; good negro cabins with brick chimneys, large framed tobacco-house, sufficient to store away charge crop, with others convenient on the farm; good stables, carriage-house, and all necessary, out-buildings; fine orchard, &c. For further particulars, any information can do had by addressing me at Keysville P. O.

div3.head: Six hundred acres of fine Lase for sale.
div3.p:
--The subscribers having enlisted for the war, offer for sale a Tract of land, containing 500 acres, lying in the lower and of Charlotte county, Va., within eight miles of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, and seven of the proposed extension of the Roanoke Valley Road, adjoining the lands of Dr. P. G. Venable, Capt. T. D. Jeffins, and Richard Russell. There are two large manufacturing mills within one mille of the farm, on Staunton river.
About one half of the Tract is in woods, the balance cleaned and in good condition.
There is between fifty and seventy- five acres of first land on the Tract.
It is well watered — Howgan's and Gardwell's creeks passage through it — This land is well adapted to the growth of all the staple crops of the State, especially wheat.
The farm is well supplied with unfailing springs of excerlont water.
The neighborhood is not surpassed by any in the State for intelligence and moral worth.
There are seven churches within eight miles of the Farm.
The buidlings are in good condition, and consisting of a comfortable dwelling and all necessary out-house.
There is on the Farm two excellent orchards of ph fruit, consisting of apples, peaches, pears, plumns, &c., and an excellent garden.
Any one deisiring to purchase, can communicate with Br. Wm. D. Hascins, Red Oak Grove, charlotte county, Va., (formerly a resident physician of Richmond,) who resides in 1½ miles of teh Farm, and will take please in showing the lands.
The camp of the undersigned is at persent on Fulton Hill, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer:
Lt. Thomas. Pettus,
4th Regiment Va., Heavy Artillery.
Lt. Edw'dl.Haskies,
56th Virginia Riglment. je 2--10t*

div3.head: Valuable Farm of 286 acres, in Chesterfield Co., on Swift creeks, 5 miles from Powhatan Depot, for sale.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the Farm located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. David M. Goode.
It contains 285 acres, of which about two-thirds are cleared, embracing about 150 acres of fine Swift creek low grounds.
Thre is on the place an excellent dwelling, containing 6 rooms, and the usual out-buildings.
Possession given in the faill, or earlier if growing crops are paid fro. Forfurther particular, apply to

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--My residence at Denpree's Old Store in county of Charlotte, seven miles from Drake's Brach Dspet, Richmond and Danville Railroad, containing 70 acres Well-timbered land with a good dwelling-house and office, nearly new; with necessary out-building, and a good well of water in the yard.
Possession given immediately.

I will also sell my residence at Drake'r Branch, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, with 12½ acres of land, nearly all in original growth, with a fine sprig of water.
The dwelling is large and handsome, with six rooms above, besides basement rooms, consisting of a large dining room, store room, panny, closets, &c., with a large double, framed kitchen, smoke house, ice house, stable, &c., with one of the best gardens in the country, and a fine young orchard, just beginning to bear, consisting of the best fruits.
All nicely palled and railed in. The outldings are all now, and situated in a beautiful oak grove, called "sampson's Hill." Apply to T. G. Broocks,
Drake's Branch.

div3.head:
House and lot at
Charlotte C. H. For sale.
div3.p: The House formerly occupied by Mr. Thomas East, containing four comfortable Rooms, long Pizzs and Store Rooms, Out-Houses, Kitchen, Dairly, Hen-house, and good Stables, a meet excellent well of water in the yard, and 12 1-6 acres of highly improved land — the garden being one of the very best.

Also, 13 acres of Dand, separated from the house lot by the Prince Edward road, three acres of which is in wood.
Taken altogether, this is a most desirable place for a small family.

Wm. B. Davidson, at
Harvey, Armlstead & Williams's.

div3.head: Dan river land for sale.
div3.p:
--578½ acres of land, belonging to the estate of John Edwards, dec'd, is offered for sale in Halifax county, Va. This land has two Dwellings, with other necessary buidlings, gardens, &c. The plantation is divided into low grounds and upland, of excellent quality.
The timbered portion is also excellent.
The whole is well watered with good springs, convenient to every park.
The terms will be accommodating.
Persons wishing to see the land will please apply to the subscriber, located near New's Ferry Depot, Richmond and Daville Railroad.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p: --My woman, Jennie, left home yesterday morning; was seen in Richmond soon after; is dark complexion, medium stature; thick, bushy hair; has a downcast look when spoken to, drawls her words; has a dark mark on one check; had on a yellow stripped domestic dress; took other clothes with her.
div3.closer:
Hez. G. Archer
Manchester June 7, 1862. je 7--3t*

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my store, on Tuesday, March 17th, my Negro boy Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto; thick-set; about 5 feet high; 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward of one hundred dollars will be paid for his delivery to me. S. S. Cottrell,
129 Main st.

div3.head: Ran away--$100 reward
div3.p:
--From Sherwood, (the late residence of Roger B. Alkinson, deed, in Lunenburg county, Va.,) on Sunday, the 20th of April, 1862, a Negro named Arch, between 17 and 18 years of age, about 5 feet 4 inches high, of black color, and pleasant countenance.--He went off dressed in drab fulled linsey frock coat, vest, and pants, black slouch bat, and course boots, worn through the winter.
He and other slaves were removed from the county of Loudoun to Sherwood early in March last, and Arch was doubtless on his way back to that county.
He was arrested and lodged in Jail on the 23d of last month at Hanover C. H. In company, however, with two other negroes, and two white men, (the two white men charged with felony,) all confined in the same room, Arch escaped front jail about the first day of this month.

One hundred dollars will be paid by me for the apprehension and delivery of said negro in some jail so that I get him again, besides all reasonable expenses.
My address is Non-Intervention P. O. Lunenburg county, Va.

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, living in Hayneville, Ala., on or about the 17th of March last, Sen. a likely mulatto boy, age about 21 years; about five and a half feet high; weighs about 140 pounds; has a fine set of teeth; a smiling, pleasant countenance, and is prompt in reply when addressed.
It is known that no was in Montgomery, Ala., on 1st April, and it is believed that he was Richmond.
Va., about the 24th April, dressed in uniform, with a sword suspended by his side.
He was raised in the neighborhood of Knoxville, Tenn., and was brought from Knoxville to Montgomery.
The above reward will be paid for his lodgment in jail, and information furnished, so that I will get him.
P. S.--He is a pretty fair carriage smith and a tolerable bricklayer, and it is believed he has changed his name.
div3.closer:
William D. Seerman.
Hayneville, Lownded cu., Ala., my 27--12t*
May 19, 1862. my 27--12t *

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, near Dayton, Marengo county, Ala., my dining-room servant, James, sometimes calling himself James Clarke, a bright mulatto, about twenty-five years of age, slightly bowlegged; was raised in Richmond, Va, by a Mr. Toll.
His parents still live there.--James was in the army last summer at Winchester.
A reasonable reward will be paid for his apprehension and confinement in jail so that I get him again.

div3.head: Medical College Hospital.
div3.p: Owing to the present extravagant prices of proviations and midicines, the charge for College Patients admitted into this Hospital, after this date, will be $3 per week until further notice.

closer.signed: L. S. Joynes, M. D., Pres't.

div3.head: Hospital of the Medical Cllege of Virginia.
div3.p:
--This Hospital, created by the liberality of the State, at a cost of more than $30,000, is now completed, and open for the reception of patients.
It is admirably adapted by its plan for the accommodation of the sick, and is furnished with every convenient.
Its situation on Marshall street, out of 12th, immediately adjacent to the Medical College, while retired and airy,is at the same time central, and convenient of access from all parts of the city.
The patients are under the immediate charge of the Professors of the College, (who make daily visits,) assisted by a competant Resident Physician.
All persons requiring Medical or Surgical treatment are admitted, except the Innane, and those laboring under Small-Pox and other Infactious Disorders,
Lying in women, both white and colored, receive special care and attention.
Including Board, Medical Attendances, &ct.
White Fatients...$6 per week.
Slaves...$5 per week.
And at the same rate fractions of a week.
For less than one week, $1 per day, up to the charge for a full week.

Several nearly furnished Private Rooms have been provided for those desiring separets accommodations.
The charge for these will vary from $7 to $30 will be required, in addition to the above weekly rates.
All charges payable on the removal of the pation.
A limited number of bead placed at the disposal of Charitable Associations, at $150 per annum, payable semi-annually, or at a corresponding rate for the purpose.
Citizens and strangers are invited to visit Hospital and inspect its arrangements.
President--Dr. L. S. Joynes.
Attending, Physicians — Drs. Tucker, Conway and McCAW.
Attending Surgeons — Drs. Gibson, Peticolas and Wellford.
Resident Physicians — Drs. Henry B. Melvin and Marshall T. Hill.
Steward — F. M. Parish.

div3.head: Bellevue Hospital Church Hill Richmond, Va.
div3.p: White Patients--In wards, $6 per week; in private rooms, $7 to $15 per week.

Slaves--$5 per week.
Less than a week, $1 per day, but not to exceed $5 per day.

No extra charges except for surgical operations, and then an additional fee ranging from $2 to $31 will be charged.
Bills payable on the removal of the patient.
No amsl admitted.

A convered spring wagon will convey patients to and from the Hospital when desired.
Orders may be left at the Hospital, or at the office of A. L. Hollapay, Thirteenth street, between Main and Cary.

The subscriber, who has been connected will the Institution since its foundation, having taken it under his exclusive charge, rided by competent assistants; solicits a continuance of the liberal patronage of his friends and of the public generally.
Atending Physician and Surgeon,

James Bolton, M. D.,

div3.head: Richmond and Dasville Rail road.
div3.p: --On and alter Friday, May 30th, the Passenger Train will sun as follows:
going West
Mail Train leaves Richmond daily at 6 o'clock A. M. and arrives at Danville at 5.47 P. M.
At Burkeville, it connects with the Train on the south-Side Railroad for the West.
At Clover, it stops 20 minutes for dinner.
going East.
Mail Train leaves Danville Daily at 5.30 A. M., and arrive at Richmond 3.21 P. M.
At Burksville, it connects with the train in the South-Side Railroad for Norfolk and Petersburg.
Trains from Danville coming down stops at Clover for Breakfast.

div3.head: Notice--Pledsiont Railroad Company.
div3.p:
--By authority vested in me by the Geneal Commissioners of the Piedmont Company at their meeting in the city of Richmond, held the 29th day of April last, requiring me to advertise for a meeting of the subscribers to the capital stock of the said company, so soon as I was advised that one hundred thousand dollars of the capital stock had been taken, and five per cent thereon paid in. In obedience thereto, I hereby give notice that I have been informed by A. Y. Stokes, Lewls E. Harvie, and Thomas.
W. Brocken brough, Commissioners appointed under the charter to receive subscriptions in the city of Richmond, that the entire capital of said company (15,000 shares) had been subscribed on the books opened by them, and the amount of five per cent, paid of the Stockholders.
Notice is hereby given that a meeting of the subscribers to the capital stock of the Piedmont Railroad will be held in the town of Greensborough, N. C., next for the purpose of organizing the company.
div3.closer:
Wm. T. Sutherlin,
Chairman of the General Comm'rs.
Danville, May 11th, 1862.
Eallegh Greensboro', and Danvills papers cons, until the 11th June my 13--t11jn

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --Merchants and others receiving freight via Richmond and Petersburg Railroad Company are hereby notified l goods are not taken away in twenty four hours after their arrival, they will be stored at their expense and risk.

div3.head:
Virginia Central Railroad,
Summer Arrangement.
div3.p: On and after Monday, May 10th, the Mail and Passenger Trains will leave Richmond for Gordonsville, Charlottesville, and Stounton, daily, at 6.20A. M., connecting at Charlottesville with the Orange and Alexandria Train for Lynchburg.
Between Staunton and Jackson's River the Mai Train will be run fri- weekly, leaving Stounton S Tuesdays, Thursday, and Saturdays, and Jackson's River on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays.
Barman & Brown's Stage Line for Lexington, connects with the Mail Train, and leaves Staunton on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, and Goshen on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays.
Harmen, Mason & Co.'s Stage Line, for White Sulphur, Lawlsburg, &c., connects with their train on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays.

The regular Thraugh Fraight Train for Gordonsville, and points most of there, leaves Richmond at 7.30 P. M. on Sundays, Tuesdays, and Thursdays, and arrive from the rest at 4 A. M. on Sundays, Wednesdays, and Fridays.
A regular Way freight Train for Gordonsvills, and points asst, leaves daily, (Sundays excepted,) at 4.30 A. M.

div3.head: Charge of Schedule.--Richmond and Petersburg Railroad.
div3.p: --On and after Monday, the 24th February, the trains on this road will run as follows:

Mail Train.--Leaves Richmond at 4.45 A. M. daily, and Petersburg at 4.15 P. M. Fraight and Accommodation Train leave Richmond daily, except Sunday,) at 6.15 A. M. and 2.45 P. M., and Petersburg at 8.55 A. M. The Mail Trains will stop only at Half-Way Station, Chestor, and Fort Wallhall Junction.
Travelers will hear in mind, that they are required to show a Pass, from the Governor, or some other authorized person, before they can leave the city by this road.

div3.head: Insurance.
div3.p:
the Virginia fire and Marins Insurance Company,
Office, No. 183,
Their new building, on Main street, next door is the Bank of Virginia, Richmond.
Surplus...$9,000.

This old institution (established by the Virginia Legislature, and in successful operation for thrity years,) continues to insure, in city and country, against loss and damage by fire, almost every description of property.
Sea risks on ships and cargoes, and risks on in-land transportation, taken to all parts of the world at reseanable sales of premiumn.
The very liberal share of the public estrouage which it has an long received, operates in return a liberal and prompt settlement of claism, which it has ever been its pleasure to observe.
Farmers, merchants, and citizens generally, may be referred to parties already insured in this company, in over 50 counties in the State.
Application, by letter or otherwise, to the President or Secretary, will meet prompt attention.
